claim:
Consider the following background information: A 14-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and is found on ultrasound to have a gallstone. Based on clinical suspicion, a CBC, a Coombs test, and a bilirubin panel are obtained to determine the etiology of the gallstone. These tests reveal a mild normocytic anemia with associated reticulocytosis as well as an increased RDW. In addition there is an indirect hyperbilirubinemia and the Coombs test results are negative. To confirm the diagnosis, an osmotic fragility test is performed which shows increased fragility in hypotonic solution.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: In this patient, hypersegmented neutrophils would most likely be anticipated if a blood smear were obtained.

supporting.text: Hypersegmented neutrophils are typically associated with megaloblastic anemia, not hemolytic anemia.

attacks.text: Hypersegmented neutrophils are typically associated with megaloblastic anemia, not hemolytic anemia.

The patient's findings (reticulocytosis, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, negative Coombs test, and increased osmotic fragility) strongly suggest hereditary spherocytosis, a type of hemolytic anemia, which does not typically involve hypersegmented neutrophils.

While hypersegmented neutrophils are classically linked to megaloblastic anemia, some cases of severe hemolytic anemia can show mild neutrophil hypersegmentation due to increased cell turnover and stress on the bone marrow.

The rarity of hypersegmented neutrophils in hemolytic anemia makes this an unlikely finding, and other explanations (e.g., concurrent vitamin B12/folate deficiency) would need to be ruled out before attributing it to the hemolytic process.

Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency is uncommon in hereditary spherocytosis unless there is significant hemolysis or poor dietary intake, making hypersegmented neutrophils unlikely in this case.
The osmotic fragility test confirms hereditary spherocytosis, which has no known association with hypersegmented neutrophils, further supporting the original argument.
